newsitem.title: UK: IFC emerging market index up 0.2 pct at 298.22.
newsitem.headline: IFC emerging market index up 0.2 pct at 298.22.

text.p: The International Finance Corporation's benchmark composite index of emerging market equities, denominated in dollars, rose 0.2 percent to 298.22 at the start of trade on Thursday.
Latin America slipped 0.5 percent day-on-day to 536.42, Asia was up 0.3 percent at 252.68 and Europe, Middle East and Africa were up 0.8 percent at 142.11.
The IFC composite index touched a 1996 high of 308.77 on July 4, up from the year's 275.79 low recorded on January 1.
ING Barings' Global Emerging Market Index BFFO, also denominated in dollars, was down 0.07 percent day-on-day at 160.93 at 0815 GMT.
The year's high was 165.948, reached on July 3. It touched the year's 148.85 low on January 2.
Morgan Stanley's dollar-denominated Emerging Markets Free index was up 0.18 percent at 481.399, calculated after the close of trade on Tuesday.
It touched a 1996 high at 505.452 on July 4. The year's 458.369 low was recorded on January 1.

All indices are capitalisation-weighted and are calculated daily. The IFC index measures returns on equities, liquid and accessible to foreign investors, from 26 emerging market countries. It is updated at 2300 GMT.
The BEMI index measures equity returns from some 20 emerging market countries, with the latest changes reported by 0900 GMT.
The MSCI Free measures equity returns from 22 emerging market nations. Changes are reported with one day's lag at 1300 GMT.

The J.P. Morgan emerging market local currency index, its returns calculated in dollar terms, rose 0.20 percent to 122.37 by the start of trade on Thursday. By region, Latin America was up 0.69 percent to 99.58, Asia rose 0.01 to 129.31, and East Europe was up 0.05 at 159.61. --Caroline Brothers, London Newsroom +44 171 542 2734
